about.short: LAN-Cam is a local-network-only camera and screen streaming tool that lets you broadcast your screen or camera feed to multiple devices over the same Wi-Fi, with low latency and zero internet dependency.
about.long:
LAN-Cam was designed to solve a recurring problem in classrooms, workshops, and small offices: how to share a live screen or camera feed with multiple nearby devices without relying on the internet, cloud services, or complex hardware setups.

The idea is simple: any laptop or phone on your local network can become a "broadcaster" or a "viewer". The broadcaster streams either its screen or camera feed; viewers join via auto-discovered sessions or a simple LAN URL/QR code. Everything stays inside the local network – making it faster, more private, and more reliable even when the internet is slow or unavailable.

LAN-Cam supports multiple scenarios: a teacher projecting their tablet to all student devices, a trainer sharing code in a classroom, a home user mirroring a phone camera to a big screen, or a small team quickly demoing something without HDMI cables. The architecture focuses on low-latency streaming, simple device discovery, and a clean, no-friction UX that non-technical users can understand.

roles_and_responsibilities: Defined the core product concept and identified key use-cases (classroom, office, home).
Designed the LAN-first architecture including discovery, signalling, and streaming paths.
Implemented the desktop sender app with screen capture and camera capture modes.
Built the web-based viewer interface for easy access via browser on LAN devices.
Created the UI flows for joining sessions via auto-discovery, PIN, or QR-based URL.
Handled packaging, configuration, and basic diagnostics/latency checks for users.
objectives: Provide a lightweight, LAN-only alternative to screen-sharing tools that depend on the internet.
Make it extremely easy for non-technical users to share their screen or camera feed locally.
Support multiple viewers simultaneously with acceptable latency over typical Wi-Fi networks.
Ensure all data stays within the local network for privacy-sensitive environments like classrooms and offices.
Prepare the codebase for future extensions like recording, annotations, and multi-room support.

core_streaming: Screen sharing from desktop/laptop to any browser on the same LAN.
Camera mode: turn the device’s webcam into a LAN camera feed.
Optional audio streaming for classes or explanation sessions.
Adaptive quality presets (Low/Medium/High) based on network conditions.
session_management: Auto-discovery of active sessions on the same LAN via broadcast/mDNS.
Join via simple URL or QR code for quick connection from phones and tablets.
viewing_experience: Browser-based viewer – no installation needed for participants.
Full-screen mode with aspect-ratio handling for different devices.
Basic latency indicator (Good/OK/Poor) based on round-trip checks.
modes_and_use_cases: Classroom mode: one broadcaster, many viewers (students on laptops/phones).
Meeting mode: switch broadcaster between multiple devices (planned).
Home theatre mode: stream from laptop/phone to TV browser on same Wi-Fi.
settings_and_admin: Toggle between screen and camera mode.
Select which display or window to share (OS-permitting).
Quality and bandwidth settings per session.
Session stats: connected viewers count, approximate bandwidth, and uptime.

core_technology: WebRTC-based streaming for low-latency audio/video over LAN.
WebSockets / signalling server for session negotiation and control.
Local network discovery via broadcast/mDNS (where supported).
desktop_app: Electron-based app (or similar framework) wrapping web technologies.
Native OS capture APIs for screen and window capture where needed.
Auto-update channel for pushing new builds.
web_client: Responsive layout optimized for laptops, tablets, and mobile phones.
Fallback modes for browsers with limited WebRTC support.
backend_and_services: Lightweight signalling server (Node.js/FastAPI) for peer coordination.
Option to run signalling on the same LAN machine or a small VPS.
No media relay by default – peers stream directly over LAN where possible.
deployment_and_ops: Self-hosted signalling server and controller (Docker-based deployment).
Desktop builds for major OSes (Windows first; macOS/Linux planned).
Configurable environment for local-only or mixed LAN/internet use.

concept_and_planning.summary: Identified classroom and small-office pain points with existing screen-sharing tools and defined the LAN-only value proposition.

prototype_v1.summary: Built initial desktop sender and browser viewer with basic WebRTC streaming on LAN.

lan_discovery_and_ux.summary: Implemented session discovery, QR-based join flow, simple configuration panel, and stabilised connectivity flows.

internal_beta.summary: Used LAN-Cam in small internal/classroom-style setups to test latency, device compatibility, and user understanding.

ongoing_improvements.summary: Adding quality presets, better diagnostics, and preparing installers and documentation for wider release.

budget.notes: Represents equivalent project value (architecture, desktop app, web client, signalling server, testing). As an in-house product, primary cost is development time and testing devices.

challenges: Handling varying Wi-Fi quality and router configurations on different local networks.
Ensuring low latency without overcomplicating the UX with technical settings.
Dealing with OS-level screen capture permissions and browser compatibility.
Implementing LAN discovery that works across different OS and router setups.
Keeping everything local by default while still allowing optional remote signalling if needed.
solutions: Introduced simple quality presets instead of exposing complex bitrate/codec settings.
Used WebRTC for peer-to-peer streaming where possible and kept the signalling layer minimal.
Added clear permission prompts and troubleshooting tips for screen and camera access.
Designed fallback join flows using manual IP/URL entry when auto-discovery fails.
Separated signalling and media layers so signalling can be local or remote, while video stays on LAN where possible.

qualitative: Created a practical LAN-first tool that removes dependence on internet-based screen-sharing for local sessions.
Enabled classroom-style broadcasting where all students can view the teacher’s screen on their own devices.
Simplified ad-hoc demo sharing in small teams without requiring cables or external services.
Laid the groundwork for a future paid/pro version with recording, multi-presenter, and annotation features.
outcomes.example_metrics_note: As a prototype/early internal tool, outcomes are measured in latency stability, connection success rate, and user feedback in limited environments. Public usage metrics will be added post beta release.
